code_alert: We performed all statistical analyses using r version 3.1.1 (R Core Team, 2014) and the lme4 package (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2015). As our experimental design used blocks, we worked with mixed models, always utilizing tree pair as random factor and including soil temperature and density of conspecific seedlings as covariables as they could influence seedling mortality, budburst delay, leaf herbivory, mycorrhization and fungal-driven decomposition. The adequacy of models to data was always checked graphically with residuals-vs.-fitted values plot and QQ plot of the residuals. Variance explained by each model was estimated by calculating the marginal R2 (i.e. variance explained by fixed factors only) and the conditional R2 (i.e. variance explained by both fixed and random factors) (Nakagawa & Schielzeth, 2013).

These were compared between populations using generalised linear models followed by Tukey's pairwise comparisons using function glht from the r package multcomp (Hothorn et al., 2008).
We tested for differences among functional groups of pollinators using analysis of variance and running paired Tukey tests in the base package in r.

We fitted GAM models using the mgcv package in r (Wood, 2011), and then calculated the statistical significance of selection coefficients via the bootstrap approach (N > 500 iterations) implemented in package gsg (Morrissey & Sakrejda, 2014). Standardisation of traits and fitness values, as well as scaling of quadratic coefficients (as explained in Stinchcombe et al., 2008), are automatically implemented by the â€˜gsgâ€™ calculations.

comments: Fifth paper I did. I took 16 minutes, in case that is useful. I feel it is important to note that the data has metadata but not a README or a data dictionary/codebook. The metadata provided is perfect, but since there is no README or data dictionary, I decided not to answer question 9. The authors provide data in an institutional repository. Since the repository does not display citations, I went to DataCite to figure it out (https://commons.datacite.org/?query=10.25829%2Fidiv.1915-15-3293). It is important to note that one of the dataset they say to provide cannot be downloaded (BEF-China website FoliarFungi2014 https://data.botanik.uni-halle.de/bef-china/datasets/635), which is why I chose â€œSome analyses can be repeated but not all (~50% of analyses can be repeated).â€ But answer the other data questions based on the dataset that was provided (iDiv Biodiversity Data Portal (iBDP) https://doi.org/10.25829/idiv.1915-15-3293).

In the dryad repositery: "This is the code and data that generates the models and figures used in the manuscript and supplementary documents.

We begin by generating an ensemble of models for each transition matrix, which are associated with the same dynamic behaviours determined through expert elicitation. To do this we first determine a scalar multiple for each transition matrix, that will be multiplied along the diagonal of the coefficient matrix and ensure that one thousand models are generated in approximately 24 hours. This is done using the Matlab script FindMultiplier.m in which a user selects the transition matrix to investigate (and its type: 1 if all signs are defined, 2 if the sign is uncertain)."

code_alert: We evaluated chain convergence using the R package Coda (Plummer et al., 2006). The models were implemented in program JAGS (Plummer, 2003) that we executed from R (R Core Team, 2019) with the package r2 jags (Su & Yajima, 2012). ... Bayesian survival trajectory analyses implemented in the R package BaSTA were used to estimate those mortality metrics (Colchero & Clark, 2012; Colchero et al., 2012). ... The outputted vcf file was further filtered using python and bash scripts from the stacks workflow RAD-seq pipeline analysis available online (https://github.com/enormandeau/stacks_workflow). ... The parameters were calculated using a custom python script (available at https://github.com/enormandeau/stacks_workflow) parsing the filtered VCF file. ... Normalization was performed using the trimmed mean of M-values method originally described for RNA-seq count normalization and implemented in the R package edgeR (Robinson & Oshlack, 2010). ... All statistical tests were implemented in Scipy v.1.5.1 in Python 3.6.3. ... We also calculated pairwise FST using the R library StAMPP (Pembleton et al., 2013) with 95% CI estimated on 1,000 bootstraps. ... We tested for linear correlations between allele frequencies and mean annual temperature using latent factor mixed models implemented in the R package lfmm 2 (Caye et al., 2019). ... For the 20 strongest CNV loci putatively associated with temperature (those with highest R2), we examined whether discrete copy number categories could be drawn from the distributions of normalized read depth using a model-based unsupervised clustering approach implemented in the R library Mclust, V. 5.4.4 (Fraley et al., 2012).

code_comments: The README for the code is a bit better than the general README, but still, missing instructions and, in this case, metadata for the code.
comments: Sixth paper I did. I took 24 minutes, in case that is useful. The repository is huge and it is not easy to say what is data and what is something else. The README (.md) is not really informative, though there seem to be files here and there with a lot of information. In the repository, there are other files that might be data, such as .js or .geojson, but I cannot really say. The data folder contains many files in various formats, some of which I cannot open. The README is not informative, so assessing the completeness of the archived data is virtually impossible without running all the code. The authors provide data and code in the same Zenodo repository. Since Zenodo does not display citations, I went to DataCite to figure it out (https://commons.datacite.org/?query=10.5281%2Fzenodo.4721426). This is possibly the most difficult paper of all six papers I have done so far. Assessing the completeness of the data is really not possible without an excessive time investment, and, from our experiences in previous similar projects, only possible once you attempt to run the code.

code_alert: e used the functions ‚Äòlmer‚Äô for the models and ‚Äòglht‚Äô for the posthoc tests from the r packages lme4 and multcomp, respectively (Bates et al., 2012; Hothorn et al., 2008). To calculate temporal beta-diversity indices, we used the function ‚ÄòTBI‚Äô (Legendre & De Caceres, 2013) from the package adespatial (Dray et al., 2019). To assess whether compositional dissimilarity of vascular epiphyte assemblages, as variation in assemblage dissimilarity independent from differences in alpha diversity, was related to differences in host tree sizes (DBH), we ran a mantel test (function ‚Äòmantel.test‚Äô) using the r package ape (Paradis & Schliep, 2019), with 999 permutations. To assess whether compositional dissimilarity of epiphyte assemblages was spatially structured, we ran a mantel correlogram (function ‚Äòmantel.correlog‚Äô) using the r package ncf (Bjornstad, 2020).To test whether mean Raup-Crick values deviated significantly from 0, we used the sign-test and the command ‚ÄòSIGN.test‚Äô from the r package bsda (Arnholt & Evans, 2017).

demo("Salmon", package = "PSPManalysis", echo = FALSE)

No data have been used in this paper, other than the contents of the PSPManalysis package available on CRAN.

code_alert: We determined population genetic structure using a PCA of Euclidian genetic distances based on allele frequencies, generated with the R package Adegenet (Jombart, 2008). We then ran a discriminant analysis of the principal components (DAPC) to identify the optimal discriminant axes that maximise the between-group variation while minimising the within-group variation. In addition, we used admixture analysis to generate ancestry coefficient plots with the snmf function in the R package LEA (Frichot & FranÃ§ois, 2015). We identified the number of population clusters existing in our dataset based on cross-entropy values and plot visualisation. We tested a range of 1â€“10 population clusters and ran five replicates for each.

The authors developed a framework, but in the process, they performed a literature review, integrated expert knowledge via surveys, and developed a summary and a synthesis across studies. The authors, however, write â€œThe manuscript does not include any primary data.â€, which I do not think is at all correct. Regarding the country where the study was performed, as far as I can understand, all people surveyed are from Germany, but that is not clear, and the authors do not provide information on that. Though the paper could have used code for some of the tasks, it all indicates that it did not.

code_alert:
Intraspecific trait variation was quantified in relation to population source (cultivar or local ecotype plots) by comparing standardized effect sizes (SES) of T-statistics calculated from testing the departure of observed trait distributions from randomized trait distributions (n = 99 permutations) using the Tstats function in the cati R package (Taudiere & Violle, 2016). 

A comparison of mean functional trait values of each species in cultivar versus local ecotype treatments were compared using one-way ANOVA in SAS (SAS Institute, 2011).

code_alert:
All analyses were performed in R, version 1.4.1717. The significance of fixed effects in linear mixed models (LMER) was calculated from F statistics with the â€˜lmerTestâ€™ package and Satterthwaite's approximation to calculate the denominator degrees of freedom. The significance of fixed effects in generalized linear mixed models (GLMER) was calculated from chi-square statistics, using Wald chi-square tests from the â€˜carâ€™ package. The distribution of residuals from the models was checked to ensure model assumptions were met and corrections for overdispersion were made when needed.

Using ImageJ analysis software (https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/index.html) from those photographs, we measured male's body size (standard length, SL, in mm; distance from the snout to the base of the caudal fin). Body size was used with body weight to quantify a male's body condition (i.e. his fat stores or surplus energy) using Fulton's body condition index (Kotrschal et al., 2011).

code_alert: With the exception of the Katz metric, which was calculated using a custom R code written by the second author, the other metrics were calculated using the R package bipaRtite (Dormann, 2011). So, we calculated the evolutionary distinctive-ness (ED; typically quantified using phylogenetic branch lengths)for each species using the Equal Splits measure implemented in the function evol.distinct from the R package picante (Kembelet al., 2010). The IVI is a combination of six metrics: degree,cluster rank, local H index, neighbourhood connectivity, between-ness and collective influence. IVI was calculated with the R package influential (Salavaty et al., 2020). To assess the role of different trait variables in explaining spe-cies centrality, we applied Bayesian GLMMs (Table S1), which usesMarkov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods to obtain the models'likelihood to non-Gaussian data. We used the function MCMCglmmimplemented in the R package McMcglMM (Hadfield, 2010).

code_comments:
the code uses a lot of field specific packages, which are being loaded a bit randomly in different parts of the process. It would help if there was a header with a list of all the packages needed, or some code checking which packages need to be installed (I had to rerun the code several times to discover all the packages I was missing).
This is typically the kind of work that would benefit a lot from using targets or at least be organised in a Rmd or qmd document. Overall the code was not very well organised.
Some parts were broken, but I am quite sure it is because the packages they used have been updated and/or because I did not run it as its own project and environment (I could easily fix it and make it run).

The relative intensity of a secondary peak (SP) was quantified by the ratio between the height of the SP and the height of the entire spectrum (following Chen, Niu, et al., 2020). Moreover, phylogenetic principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted (using the phyl.pca function in the R package phytools; Revell, 2012) on the spectral data to construct a spectral space, in which the comparison between flowers and fruits was made.

NOT ALL OF THE CODE IS ARCHIVED:
 To compare the data matrices, we performed multiple response permutation procedure (MRPP) with the R-package vegan (v.2.5-6; https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=vegan ) in R (version 3.6.0; RCoreTeam, 2020).
Principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) was calculated using R version 4.0.4 by using the function â€˜pcoâ€™ in the package ecodist: (v. 2.0.7), using the data matrix of the metabolomics dataset with â€˜Brayâ€“Curtisâ€™ as dissimilarity measure. The distance matrix was calculated using the package vegan (v. 2.5-7) and the function â€˜vegdistâ€™. PERMANOVA was calculated using the â€˜adonis2â€™ function in vegan with â€˜Brayâ€“Curtisâ€™ as distance measure.

code_alert:
We tested differences in grass cover, volume and patch size across the treatments and plot sizes using a Kruskalâ€“Wallis and Dunn's post hoc comparison test (Dunn, 1961). We also calculated the effect size of the Kruskalâ€“Wallis test (Kotrlik & Williams, 2003) based on the H-statistic to determine the percentage of variance in the vegetation metrics explained by the treatment effect using the R package rstatix (Kassambara, 2020). The H-statistic was interpreted as follows: values >0.01 but <0.06 (small effect), >0.06 but <0.14 (moderate effect) and â‰¥0.14 (large effect). We used kernel density estimation (plotted in the R package ggplot2, R Core Team, 2021) to compare the distribution of grass height and short grass patch sizes across the fire treatments.

To evaluate the spatial continuity of short grasses patches, we constructed semivariograms in the gstat R package (Pebesma & Graeler, 2023).

data_availability_text: The data is not readily available online. We took this measure aiming to respect the autonomy of the community and prioritize the protection of privacy and cultural sensitivities. The data used in this paper was collected on the Collective Land of IpetÃ­ EmberÃ¡ and thus belongs to the community. Moreover, some species planted have a high commercial value, and neighbouring communities have had issues with illegal harvesting. We thus encourage researchers seeking access to data collected within the collective land of IpetÃ­ EmberÃ¡ to reach out to the local authorities of the Alto Bayano Congreso.

code_alert: To examine the effects of landscape on the number of workers, larvae and provisions in a colony, we compared models containing the first two principal components using Akaike's information criterion adjusted for sample size (AICc) with the model.sel function in the MuMIn package (Barton, 2019). The fixed effects for these four models included: (a) Sampling period only, (b) Sampling period + PC1, (c) Sampling period + PC2 and (d) Sampling period + PC1 + PC2. We included the random effect of site in all models, fit models with a negative binomial distribution using the glmer.nb function in the lme4 package (Bates, MÃ¤chler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014), and analysed models for the worker, larval and provisions datasets separately.

code_alert: Expression values generated by edgeR were used for examining profiles of expression across different samples through a hierarchical clustering. A heatmap of DEGs was generated using the heatmap3 package in r v3.2.2 (R Core Team, 2015). To assess overall similarity across samples, their relationships were also explored through a PCA on the transposed normalized expression matrix with r v3.2.2. Venn diagrams to identify shared and unique DEGs between different contrasts were performed with http://bioinformatics.psb.ugent.be/webtools/Venn/. GO-term enrichment analysis of DEGs was performed through the Fisher's exact test approach by using the GO enrichment analysis function provided by Blast2GO v.5 with a threshold FDR of 0.05. Due to a large list of enriched GO terms was obtained in SAM comparisons, a further reduction to most specific terms (FDR < 0.01) was carried out. Summarization and visualization of GO terms were performed by using the REVIGO web service (http://revigo.irb.hr/; Supek, BoÅ¡njak, Å kunca, & Å muc, 2011).

Data were analysed using (generalised) linear mixed-effects models ([G]LMMs) using the â€˜lme4â€™ package (Bates et al., 2015) in â€˜râ€™ (R Core Team, 2020) and 95% confidence intervals for parameter estimates were generated by bootstrapping (1,000 samples using â€˜bootMerâ€™ [â€˜lme4â€™ package]).

Using â€˜ict.testâ€™ (r package â€˜listâ€™; Blair & Imai, 2010), we found no evidence of a design effect (p values between 0.31â€“1 for each list item; Whytock et al., 2018).

We tested for the effect of illegal offtake and return rate on measures of population growth and extinction probability using generalised additive models (GAMs, using Gaussian and binomial error structures for growth and extinction probability respectively; r package â€˜mgcvâ€™; Wood, 2011). All analyses were carried out in r (R Core Team, 2020).

code_alert:
3 Statistical analysis

We used modified binomial power analyses to assess our ability to detect P. destructans arrival at each site where no positive samples were detected. We first calculated an expected early prevalence at each site where P. destructans was not detected in early hibernation based on a weighted mean prevalence. The weighted mean prevalence was calculated as the average prevalence of each species at sites where P. destructans was detected in early hibernation multiplied by the proportional abundance of a given species at each site (Table S1). We then calculated the probability of missing P. destructans at a site as the probability of getting all negatives in bats given the expected prevalence at a site multiplied by the probability of missing P. destructans in the unsampled bats (calculation shown in Appendix S1).

We investigated the effect of timing of P. destructans arrival on late winter prevalence by fitting a GLMM with a binomial distribution and a logit link. We included fixed effects for the timing of P. destructans detection (early or late hibernation) interacting with the effect of species, and included site as a random effect. We also examined the effect of timing of P. destructans detection on fungal loads using a linear mixed model with species and timing of detection as interacting fixed effects, and site as a random effect. Lastly, we assessed the effect of the timing of P. destructans introduction on log10 bat population growth rates, calculated as the annual change in late winter counts at each site, using linear mixed models with species interacting with timing of detection as fixed effects and site as a random effect. We explored the inclusion of autumn prevalence as a continuous variable (0 for all sites and species where P. destructans was not detected, prevalence in each species ranged between 0 and 0.25 for sites where P. destructans was detected during autumn) and the results were qualitatively similar to those shown, so we present the discretization (early or late winter P. destructans detection) for simplicity of visualization and interpretation.

Lastly, we investigated evidence of overwinter movements of bats among sites. At each site, we calculated our response variable, overwinter urn:x-wiley:00218790:media:jane13439:jane13439-math-0001 as the proportional change in the number of bats of each species at a site by dividing the late hibernation count by the early hibernation count. We then used a linear mixed model to assess the relationship between log10(overwinter urn:x-wiley:00218790:media:jane13439:jane13439-math-0002) and log10(early hibernation colony size) with an additive or interactive effect of species and site as a random effect.

code_alert: To be able to use all observations in our statistical analyses, we used predictive mean matching, implemented in the mice r package (Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011) to impute these missing values based on the variables included in the SEM model. The PCA was performed on the correlation matrix of the litter traits using the vegan package (Oksanen et al., 2019). The dimension of forest floor properties (quantitative, ordinal and nominal) was reduced through a Gower dissimilarity-based PCoA, performed with the ape package (Paradis & Schliep, 2018). Because of the many zero values present in the earthworm biomass data, all relations with biomass as a response variable were modelled with zero-inflated-mixed models (ZIMM) with Gaussian error distribution using the nbzimm package. The GAMM was performed with the mgcv package. The SEMs were fit using the lavaan package (Rosseel, 2012).Because zero-inflated models with Gaussian error distribution cannot yet be incorporated in the mgcv and lavaan packages. The dimension of forest floor properties (quantitative, ordinal and nominal) was reduced through a Gower dissimilarity-based PCoA, performed with the ape package (Paradis & Schliep, 2018).

comments:
Not actual issues, but I made the following assumptions based on Discord discussion.
(1) General-Q7: YES. Paper has data, archived for public use, upon request, but is embargoed. Availability statement provides instruction to access the data.
(2) Code-Q01: NO. Authors use MARK software (a GUI interface). There are no references in the text about the use of any programming language for the main analysis.

The data set look completed but once I opened the R script I found this one, "TRYdata <- fread("5052.txt", header = T, sep = "\t", dec = ".", quote = "", data.table = T)"

comments:
Not a problem, but when I first looked at the dataset, it seemed complete. However, once I opened the R script, I found the following line:

TRYdata <- fread("5052.txt", header = T, sep = "\t", dec = ".", quote = "", data.table = T)

This suggests that a file, "5052.txt," is necessary but is not available with the data. It may have been generated by other scripts, but this is not mentioned on the Figshare page, which serves as the README.

We used the Moran eigenvector filtering function (r package spdep) to account for possible effects of spatial autocorrelation on parameter estimates (Bivand et al., 2015). Pseudo-R2 of GLMs were calculated by the relationship â€˜1 âˆ’ residual deviance/null devianceâ€™.

data_availability_text:
Climatic data (average relative humidity and minimum temperature) were collected from the Brazilian public repository â€˜Meteorological database for education and researchâ€™ (banco de dados meteorolÃ³gicos para ensino e pesquisa) available at the BDMEP website for several cities of Brazil (period 2005â€“2016). These data are free to access, use and archive (conditions at INMET website). The climatic data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (LourenÂ¸co, 2019).
WorldClim V2 global data (Fick & Hijmans, 2017) were downloaded from a public repository online (https://www.worldclim.org/). Updated in July 2016, these data contain average monthly climatic measurements, representative of the period 1970â€“2000. The spatial resolution used for the maps of Brazil and South America was of 10 minutes (urn:x-wiley:2041210X:media:mee313205:mee313205-math-0047). The spatial resolution used for the maps of Honduras was 2.5 minutes (urn:x-wiley:2041210X:media:mee313205:mee313205-math-0048). These data are not made available in this manuscript due to license restrictions, but are publicly available at WorldClim webpage (https://www.worldclim.org/). See Supporting Information S2 Text for more details.
Dengue notification data (by clinical evaluation, not molecularly confirmed) were obtained from the Brazilian ministry of health, available at the TABNET webportal. These notification data included the total number of dengue cases per month, per year, over the period 2007â€“2012 for the main municipality of each city. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (LourenÂ¸co, 2019).
Dengue and chikungunya incidence from Tegucigalpa (city) for the year 2015 were taken from the study by Zambrano et al. (2017) with permission from Elsevier (license number 4576391190534). Counts were collected by the national surveillance system and refer to cases clinically and laboratory confirmed (by serology and RT-PCR). Data series were extracted from Figure 5 using Engauge Digitizer Software V10.4 (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.2585387).
Zika incidence from Tegucigalpa (city) for the year 2016 is the same as in our previous study by ThÃ©zÃ© et al. (2018). Counts refer to suspected, not confirmed cases. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (LourenÂ¸co, 2019).
Aedes aegypti suitability score for Tegucigalpa (city) and Honduras (country level) is the same as in our previous study by ThÃ©zÃ© et al. (2018). The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (LourenÂ¸co, 2019).
Climate data (minimum temperature and humidity 2005â€“2013) per day for Tegucigalpa (city) was obtained from the National Centers for Environmental Information of the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NCDC NOAA) (free to be accessed at https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov). The weather station ID was 78720099999, located at the Toncontin International Airport. The data used are made available on Figshare https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.4485503 (LourenÂ¸co, 2019).

data_availability_text: All data used in this manuscript were obtained from publicly available sources. Maximum dispersal distances are available from Tamme et al. (2014). Traits are available from the KEW Seed Information Database (Royal Botanic Gardens Kew, 2016, available from http://data.kew.org/sid/), the TRY Plant Trait Database (Kattge et al., 2011, version 3.0, available from https://www.try-db.org), and the LEDA Traitbase (Kleyer et al., 2008, available from http://www.uni-oldenburg.de/en/biology/landeco/research/projects/leda/). Demographic information is available from the COMPADRE Plant Matrix Database (Salguero-GÃ³mez et al., 2015, available from http://www.compadredb.org/). Taxonomic information was obtained from The Taxonomic Name Resolution Service using all available data sources (Boyle et al., 2013; The Taxonomic Name Resolution Service), including Tropicos (Missouri Botanical Garden), USDA (USDA, NRCS), Global Composite Checklist (Flann, 2009), The Plant List (2013), and International Legume Database and Information Service, and the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group III (available from http://www.mobot.org/MOBOT/research/APweb/).
code_alert:
We obtained a phylogeny by trimming down the tree made available by Zanne et al. (2014) to the number of species used in each analysis using the package ape (Paradis, Claude, & Strimmer, 2004) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
We used parallel analysis to simulate 95th percentile eigenvalues from 100 simulated analyses and determine the number of retained principal components (Franklin, Gibson, Robertson, Pohlmann, & Fralish, 1995; Horn, 1965) using the function f a.parallel in the psych package (Revelle, 2017) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
To control for non-independence among lineages in our study, we conducted a phylogenetically informed PCA using the package phytools (Revell, 2012) in r (R Core Team, 2017).
For each PCA, we used the imputePCA function of the missMDA (Josse & Husson, 2016) package in r (R Core Team, 2017) to impute missing values. For the of 141 species, a total of 8.2% (116) of the 1,410 possible trait values were missing.
To examine whether a plant's mode of dispersal, growth form and matrix dimension (i.e. life cycle complexity) explain the location of a species along the major principal components, we used an ANOVA with Type 1 SS (Hector, Von Felten, & Schmid, 2010) including matrix dimension, dispersal mode, growth form and their two-way interactions as predictors (function aov in r, R Core Team, 2017).
To ensure our results were not affected by statistical dependence among the principal components, we conducted a permutational ANOVA on the first three principal components using Euclidian distance and 9,999 permutations with the function adonis in the package vegan (Oksanen et al., 2017) in r (R Core Team, 2017). As the results for the permutational ANOVA (Table S9) were the same as the results for the ANOVA, we report the results obtained from the ANOVA here. All analyses were conducted in r (R Core Team, 2017).

code_alert: We formulate a model for jointly optimizing the selection of river protected areas and barrier removals. Given a set of biodiversity elements (i.e., habitat classes) in need of conservation, the aim of the model is to maximize longitudinal connectivity between selected areas through targeted barrier removals, subject to lower/upper limits on the amounts of protected habitat and a cap on the number of barrier removals.

code_alert: The average multifunctionality, multiple threshold multifunctionality and turnover approaches were calculated using the â€˜multifuncâ€™ package (Byrnes et al., 2014). We calculated the correlation strength among ecosystem variables to down-weight highly correlated functions. e investigated the relationships of the overall multitrophic richness (all trophic groups) and simplified multitrophic richness (excluding each trophic group at each step) with the different multifunctionality indexes (averaging multifunctionality and five multifunctional thresholds) using linear mixed-effect models (LMEs) available in the package nlme (Pinheiro et al., 2013). As we had many trophic groups, we reduced the number of trophic groups in the pSEM using Akaike information criteria corrected for small sample size (AICc), which is implemented in the piecewiseSEM package (Lefcheck, 2016). The pSEM was fitted using a linear mixed-effect model in the piecewiseSEM package, with seasons nested within years within each lake as random factor.

data_availability_text: The Standardized Project Gutenberg Corpus used in this study is available in the repository pgcorpus/Gutenberg at GitHub (https://github.com/pgcorpus/gutenberg) or at Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/record/2422561) as a permanent record (Gerlach & Font-Clos, 2018) and was reduced using a list of key words (see Appendices A1 and A2) as described in section 2.1. The data of Wikidata and Wikispecies used to generate the database of taxon labels and part of the metadata for authors and their works in this study are available as database dumps from Wikimedia (https://dumps.wikimedia.org).
code_alert: NA
comments:
Admittedly, I did struggle to fill in this entry as they used a preexisting dataset but did not link the code they used or their modified dataset. Therefore, could you please take a look at it, if you can?
Also, they used two 'datasets': the Project Gutenburg Corpus which is a storing of many pieces of literature typed into the dataset, and a list of terms for species that they got from Wikispecies and Wikimedia. It seems that they only linked to Project Gutenburg, did not link to where they got their species list, and did not archive their filtered Gutenburg dataset or their filtered taxon term list. 
They also did not say how they actually filtered and analysed the datasets. The Project Gutenburg websites seem to say how to do so by code but they are not directly referenced.

I am not sure where I should have written this but as this is the last paper I will be able to analyse, I needed to give a word on how long it took me to analyse each paper:
It would take me a few hours for each paper. Papers that did archive their data, code and READMEs took the longest, compared to those that did not. 
What took longest was comparing the archived data to the methods as it involved meticulously reading the methods to ensure absolutely all the necessary data to reproduce the results were there. Evaluating the READMEs and annotations also took long, though not nearly as long.    
The amount of time I took is because I am unfortunately an outlier with ADHD, which makes reading anything, especially the thick complex texts of academic papers, quite difficult.
